parameters.html:
Transcript

0:02 I think it's important for JavaScript developers to really

0:05 use these tools and build them into your applications as well.

0:09 I hope that this course will help you with that.

0:12 When building applications using large language models,

0:15 there are common steps that many developers use.

0:18 LangChain.js make these steps much easier for JavaScript developers.

0:24 For example, if you're building a retrieval augmented generation or

0:27 RAG application, you'd have to choose an LLM to

0:30 perform your task, figure out how to retrieve relevant texts to

0:34 fill the element's context, tune the prompt and maybe also pause

0:38 the element's text output into something more structured for the downstream

0:42 steps of your application.

0:44 Tools that help you connect these steps and

0:46 also enable you to quickly tune this workflow,

0:49 for example, swapping out one LLM for another,

0:52 these tools are called orchestrators.

0:56 LangChain is a very popular open source orchestrator for

1:00 LLM applications and will help you to build your LLM applications much

1:04 more quickly.

1:05 The instructor for this course is Jacob Lee,

1:08 founding software engineer at LangChain and

1:11 lead maintainer for the open source LangChain.js

1:15 Jacob has worked with many developers to help

1:18 them integrate into the web and mobile applications.

1:22 Thank you, Andrew.

1:24 And I'm really excited about what you'll be

1:26 able to learn in this course.

1:27 You will learn about a number of elements

1:30 which are common in LLM applications, like data loaders,

1:33 which make it convenient to pull data from common sources,

1:37 such as PDFs, websites, databases, and more,

1:39 to augment the LLMs generation.

1:42 There's parsers. LLMs operate with natural language, while

1:45 programming languages operate with formatted data.

1:49 Parsers extract and format natural language

1:51 output to create structured forms for

1:52 your downstream code to process.

1:55 There's prompts, which are used to provide the LLM context.

1:59 Models, which provide an abstraction layer

2:01 on top of specific LLMs, so that you can write applications

2:04 that are themselves not vendor-specific.

2:08 And then there are other modules to support RAGs,

2:10 such as text splitters and integrations with vector stores.

2:14 You'll also use the LangChain Expression Language, or

2:17 LCEL for short, to easily compose complex chains

2:20 of these modules.

2:22 Quite a few people had contributed to make this course possible.

2:25 We're grateful to Harrison Chase, founder and CEO of LangChain, as

2:29 well as Nuno Campos, also from LangChain. And

2:32 on the dblend.ai side, Geoff Ladwig and Esmaell Gargari

2:35 also contributed to this course.

2:38 So lots of great stuff to learn here.

2:41 And after this course, I hope you really

2:43 built some really cool LLM-based applications in JavaScript.

2:47 Jacob, what's with the parrot in the LangChain logo?

2:51 You know, Andrew, I'm not really sure, but it's become

2:53 part of the uniform.
